previewParagraphs: Boxing Day brings a Championship clash at The Den as Millwall host Ipswich Town. While both sides have impressed so far this season, the visitors arrive with momentum and history in their favor. The stakes are high as both teams aim to boost their promotion ambitions before the year’s turn.

Millwall enter this fixture holding sixth place after 22 matches, having claimed 10 wins, 5 draws, and 7 defeats. Their current goal difference stands at -6 from 25 scored and 31 conceded, indicating a side with quality but also moments of vulnerability, especially defensively. In their last six outings, Millwall have been inconsistent, alternating between strong performances and setbacks, recording three victories, one draw, and two losses.

However, a closer look reveals an issue in recent weeks. Millwall have not managed to win any of their last three matches in all competitions. This dip in form comes at a time when their aspirations for the playoffs hinge on maintaining momentum during a congested schedule.

The Den, though, has provided some solace. Over their last three home fixtures, Millwall have recorded two wins and one loss, scoring 1.67 goals per match but also conceding at the same rate. Their attacking numbers at home are promising, with an average of 18.67 shots per game, 7 of which hit the target. Positional play also improves at home, as shown by a slight uptick in possession to 50.67% compared to their away numbers.

Their recent head-to-head history with Ipswich Town on home turf is more mixed. Out of the last three encounters at The Den, Millwall have managed one win but suffered two losses. On a brighter note, they have gone undefeated in six of their last seven home matches overall, a trend that speaks to the challenge Ipswich will face breaking them down in front of their own goal.

Turning to the visitors, Ipswich Town hold a strong third place in the standings, with 10 wins, 7 draws, and just 5 losses from 22 matches. Their offense has been particularly effective, netting 38 goals for an average of 1.73 per game, and enjoying a +15 goal differential. The last six games mirror Millwall’s results—three wins, one draw, and two defeats—but the overall picture is one of consistent progress.

Ipswich's away form deserves attention. Although just three wins in their last six on the road shows room for improvement, the Tractor Boys have notched up 80% winless outings in their last 15 away matches, which could raise some concerns. Offensively, they score 1.67 per match away and average 14.17 shots, but possession is even higher than Millwall, averaging 53.67% in all venues, showing a team that likes to control the game.

previewParagraphs: Coventry City and Swansea City lock horns at the Coventry Building Society Arena on Boxing Day, with the league leaders eager to reinforce their title aspirations. For Swansea, this fixture comes at a critical moment as they seek to reverse their recent run of poor away form and climb out of the bottom third of the Championship table.

The last time these two teams faced each other, Coventry City asserted their superiority on Swansea's home turf with a 2-0 victory. In that encounter, Coventry showcased clinical finishing and an effective counter-attacking approach. Despite Swansea dominating ball possession at 57%, it was Coventry who created more dangerous opportunities with 45 dangerous attacks compared to Swansea's 32. Swansea also managed 5 shots on target out of 7 total attempts, but Coventry’s 16 shots highlighted their willingness to test the opposition. Goals from Ellis Simms in the 17th minute and Brandon Thomas-Asante in the 44th minute sealed the three points for Coventry, underlining their ability to convert key moments into a decisive advantage.

Coventry City’s form coming into this match has been largely impressive, both overall and especially at home. Frank Lampard's side are now first in the standings, having picked up 14 wins from 22 matches with only two defeats. Their attack is firing, delivering an average of 2.41 goals per game, backed by a positive goal difference of +30. Recent form at home is even more striking: three consecutive home wins with an average of 2.33 goals scored and just one conceded per game.

Looking at longer-term trends, Coventry remain undefeated in 17 of their last 20 matches in all competitions and have come away with victory by a margin of two or more goals in 8 of those 20. Home form has been formidable; they have avoided defeat in 93% of their last 15 outings at this ground and boast nine wins from their previous 12 home matches—including a 50% trend of home victories by margins of two or more goals.

Swansea City, in contrast, have experienced a more turbulent campaign under Vitor Matos. Sitting 19th after 22 games, they have managed just 7 wins and lost 10, conceding 30 goals while netting only 24. Their recent away record is particularly concerning. In their last 11 away matches, Swansea have failed to secure a win in 9 of them. The Swans also lost each of their previous three away matches, scoring just once while shipping eight goals in total.

Short-term data reflects similarly mixed form: three wins and three losses in their last six fixtures. Even so, Swansea hold a 50% win trend over these games, showing patches of quality. But on the road they have averaged just 1 goal per game and 4.33 shots on target over their last three away fixtures, numbers that may not be enough against a solid Coventry defense.

Sidelined players could influence starting choices. For Coventry City, Oliver Dovin remains unavailable with a long-term injury, but he has not featured in recent lineups. Swansea are missing Manuel Benson, who is absent due to Achilles tendon problems—a blow to their attacking depth.
Based on recent selections and current availability, the predicted starting elevens are as follows:

originalTitle: Coventry City Aim to Extend Home Dominance Against Struggling Swansea City

previewParagraphs: Stoke City and Preston North End prepare to face off at the Bet365 Stadium in a Championship clash that brings together two sides with contrasting patterns this season. Both teams sit in the top half, but their runs of form and previous encounters suggest an evenly matched contest is on the cards.

Stoke City's home record against Preston North End hasn't provided the hosts with much comfort in recent meetings. Out of the last three matches played at Bet365 Stadium between these two teams, Stoke have failed to secure a win, managing just one draw and suffering two defeats.
This trend underscores a challenge for Mark Robins’ side, who have struggled to establish dominance at home over their Lancashire visitors in recent years.

Stoke City’s recent matches have been mixed. In their last six outings, they have picked up two wins and lost four times, without a single draw. Goals have been hard to come by, with the side netting an average of only 1 per match and conceding 1.5 on average.

Interestingly, their home performances over their last three matches offer a glimmer of hope: two victories and one defeat. At home, Stoke have improved their attacking output, scoring an average of 2 goals per match while conceding just 1. Defensively, they've kept things relatively tight, and their shooting accuracy at Bet365 Stadium is reflected in an average of 5.67 shots on target per game.

Preston North End arrive at this fixture on a strong unbeaten stretch. The visitors haven’t tasted defeat in any of their last six games, sharing the points four times and winning twice. Offensively, they’ve produced 1.5 goals per match while allowing just 1.17. Away from home, their last three games have yielded two wins and a draw.

The Lilywhites’ attack remains persistent, with an average of 10.83 shots per match and 3.83 of those testing opposition goalkeepers. However, their possession metrics are on the lower side, averaging 43.5% over the last six matches, indicating a focus on direct play and counterattacks.
